Description: Upper body sherd of Corinthian black-figured pottery column-krater; interior glazed black; exterior: from top, part of black band at junction of neck and shoulder; incised palmette and lotus frieze with added red on fronds and kalyxes; black-figure decoration consisting of male figure (top of head remaining) to right(?).
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

The sherd may belong to the same vase as Reading 26.2.90, Cambridge Museum of Classical Archaeology NA165, and Boston 86.631. The vase is probably by a painter in the Three Maidens group (Early-Middle Corinthian). For the drawing of the floral elements and the proportion of lotus to palmette, see Basel, Antiken museum in AJA 60 (1956), pl.75 fig. 34-35, which Benson, in AJA 73 (1969), p. 120, no. B 1a, attributes to the manner of the Memnon Painter. The Louvre E 630 sherd (in Payne p.154, fig. 62c; NC 1181D) is attributed by Benson in AJA 73 (1969) p.120, D2, to the Detriot Painter. The Boston sherd was found in the region of the Sanctuary of Apollo.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 64, pl. 51, no. 227)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 220)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GB.190) (phase 3)
